awd_titl_txt: RUI: Quantum Fidelity in Multimode Optical Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
As electronic devices continue to increase their processing speeds, the demand for high speed internet communications and data networks will require new technologies for storing and processing large amounts of data. Electronics are built on the use of the electron to carry and process information, and in an analogous way the field of photonics is developing devices that use particles of light (photons) to carry and process information. Individual photons obey the laws of quantum mechanics, so in order to fully understand the operation of photonic devices, quantum measurements will be performed on these new devices. One particularly essential component is a memory or information storage device. Many candidates for photonic memory exist but few have been characterized at the quantum (few-photon) level. This research program will apply new techniques for measuring the quantum properties of light to a variety of photonic memory devices. The result will be a deeper understanding of device operation that may lead to optimized devices for future applications.

Photonic memory devices have been demonstrated using slow and stored-light protocols based on Electromagnetically Induced Transparency (EIT) in Rubidium. The goal of this program is to measure the quantum state of light retrieved from several implementations of these devices in both warm and cold Rubidium vapor samples. The light stored and retrieved from such systems will be measured and analyzed using a highly efficient array of low-noise photodetectors. This technique can simultaneously measure multiple optical modes and will be used to correlate multiple modes and determine which modes (or combinations of modes) are most robust under different storage conditions. A full quantum-mechanical understanding of the optical signal retrieved from memory allows complete characterization of the device performance and will inform future work in the development of photonic memory devices.

por.por_cntn:
This research program has advanced discovery in the field of quantum optics by refining a technique to measure the complete state of a very weak beam of light--one containing only a few photons. Such measurements will be used to characterize new devices that are being developed to replace electronic systems for processing and storing information; as well as to develop free-space optical communication technologies.

Interferometric optical techniques and low-noise camera technology were used to perform measurements of very weak beams of light after they are transmitted through optical memory devices, free-space, and highly-scattering materials. In addition to studying optical memory systems, we are applying these measurement techniques to free-space optical communication systems such as those in use for quantum key distribution. Our measurement technique provides quantum-state information for multimode optical fields such as those used in free-space and optical memory devices. The results of these measurements drive further research in optical memory and free-space optical communications.

The outcomes of this research project serve to benefit society by enabling new technologies, training future scientists, and creating learning environments to serve future students. Federal support of this research effort supported the training of six undergraduate students who performed research as part of their undergraduate degree program. Each of these students was involved in the research at every level and gained valuable experience in research techniques, scientific communication, and project management.

Specific research results, generated products, and relevant methods are all available via open access methods in order to provide as much benefit as possible to a wide public audience. Papers and presentations related to this project are available through the PI's professional website and computer source code is available via public repository.
